item.title: Judge Says He Will Order Ex-Columbia Student Khalil Freed From Detention
item.description: NEW YORK (AP) — A federal judge on Friday ordered the U.S. government to free former Columbia University graduate student Mahmoud Khalil from the immigration detention center where he has been held since early March while the Trump administration sought to deport him over his role in pro-Palestinian protests.

media:content.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil is seen at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment on the Columbia University campus in New York, April 29, 2024. (AP Photo/Ted Shaffrey, File)

item.title: Deal, Not Bombs, Seen as Only Way to End Iranian Nuclear Threat
item.description: While President Donald Trump weighs whether to join Israel’s assault on Iran, foreign policy veterans and analysts argue that a negotiated settlement, not bombs nor commandos, is the only way to eliminate the threat of Tehran gaining a nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, John Bowker, Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Foreign ministers attend a working lunch in Geneva on June 20.

item.title: Harvard Nears ‘Mindbogglingly’ Historic US Deal, Trump Says
item.description: President Donald Trump said his administration has been holding talks with Harvard University and may announce a deal over the next week, potentially ending a standoff that has jeopardized billions of dollars of the school’s funding and ignited a rollicking legal fight.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 20, 2025. Trump signaled he would give diplomacy a chance before deciding whether to strike Iran, dialing back on recent comments that suggested military action could be imminent.

item.title: Carney Bill to Speed Projects Passes Vote Despite Indigenous Opposition
item.description: Canada’s House of Commons cleared a bill to accelerate the building of major projects such as pipelines, but Indigenous groups are threatening to force a legal battle over it.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: The LNG Canada project in British Columbia under construction in 2022.

item.title: Trump Says Spain Has to Pay as NATO Seeks Deal on Spending
item.description: NATO allies are pressing Spain to sign on to a stepped-up defense spending target and end a holdout that US President Donald Trump portrayed as unacceptable.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Spanish military personnel prepare Leopard 2E tanks during a training exercise for the Ukrainian military, at the San Gregorio military base outside Zaragoza, Spain, on Monday, March 13, 2023. The issue of military aid for Ukraine has stoked tensions within Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez’s governing coalition with its junior partner, the far-left Unidas Podemos party, urging the administration to focus on pushing for peace instead of sending weaponry.

item.title: Trump Sends Mixed Signals on Iran Strikes With Ceasefire Hint
item.description: Donald Trump deepened uncertainty about his readiness to join Israel’s week-old war with Iran, signaling he might consider backing a ceasefire but also warning that he could order military action sooner than the deadline he flagged just a day earlier.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse, Alisa Odenheimer, Samy Adghirni, Ellen Milligan

item.title: Trump Keeps the World Waiting With Deadlines and Deferrals
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Friday, White House correspondent Akayla Gardner delivers a roundup of the key news and events in politics, policy and economics that you need to know. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

item.title: America the Avoidable: Why Trump’s Policies Could Cost US Tourism Billions
item.description: On today’s Big Take podcast: How President Trump’s “American First” policies have kept international tourists away, forecasted to cost the US travel industry billions.
item.dc:creator: David Gura, K Oanh Ha, Rachael Lewis-Krisky

media:content.media:description: A reflection of the Statue of Liberty as passengers ride the Staten Island ferry in New York.

item.title: Harvard Gets Longer Reprieve From Trump Foreign Student Ban
item.description: A federal judge issued a new order that allows Harvard University to continue enrolling foreign students while the school fights the Trump administration’s efforts to prevent it from doing so.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Graduating Harvard University students walk through Harvard Square in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on May 29. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Finds Israel May Have Broken Human Rights Terms in Accord
item.description: A report commissioned by the European Union found that Israel may have broken the humanitarian terms of the accord that dictates their bilateral relations.
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Lynch, Alberto Nardelli, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians at the Jabaliya refugee camp in northern Gaza, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. France and Saudi Arabia are working on a proposal to disarm the Iran-backed militant group Hamas and pave the way for its demobilization, according to people familiar with the discussions.

item.title: Under New Leadership, OAS Is Determined to Show Progress on Haiti
item.description: Amid pressure from Washington to resolve the crisis in Haiti, the new head of the Western Hemisphere’s top multilateral organization pledged to work with the United Nations and international donors to chart a roadmap for peace in the violence-torn island nation.
item.dc:creator: Jim Wyss, Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Albert Ramdin Photographer: Urs Flueeler/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: NYC Sets Smaller Driver Pay Bump After Uber, Lyft Pushback
item.description: New York City on Friday announced new minimum-pay rules for rideshare drivers, settling on a smaller-than-proposed 5% increase following pushback from Uber Technologies Inc. and Lyft Inc.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung

media:content.media:description: Lyft Inc. and Uber Technologies Inc. logos a vehicle in New York.

item.title: Niger Junta Seizes French Nuclear Giant Orano’s Uranium Mine
item.description: Niger’s military government took control of Orano SA’s uranium mine, escalating a standoff with the French nuclear-power company.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: Orano branding.

item.title: Trump Allowed to Keep Using National Guard in LA for Now
item.description: President Donald Trump can continue to use California National Guard troops to respond to protests in Los Angeles as a legal challenge over the deployment proceeds, a federal appeals court ruled.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg, Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: California National Guard in Downtown Los Angeles. Photographer: Jim Vondruska/Getty Images

item.title: No Urgent Need for Key Producers to Aid Oil Market, Putin Says
item.description: The global oil market so far does not call for any additional steps from producers amid the conflict between Israel and Iran as the tensions have had only a limited effect on prices, according to Russia’s President Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: Crude oil storage tanks at the Juaymah Tank Farm in Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, on Monday, Oct. 1, 2018. Saudi Arabia is seeking to transform its crude-dependent economy by developing new industries, and is pushing into petrochemicals as a way to earn more from its energy deposits. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Why a Remote UK Base Makes the US-Iran Standoff So Difficult for Starmer
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer will be relieved by US President Donald Trump’s move to delay a decision for now on striking Iran, giving the British leader more time to address the vexing issue of providing military support.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: The Diego Garcia military base.

item.title: US Sanctions Target Iran Defense Industry, Houthis
item.description: The US escalated pressure on Iran with sanctions targeting individuals and companies allegedly involved in obtaining machinery for its defense industry, as well as those backing a militant group with ties to the regime.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle

media:content.media:description: Heavy weapons, including ballistic missiles, air defense systems and unmanned aerial vehicles, during a parade at Baharestan Square in Tehran.

item.title: Russia Says Israel, US Pledge Staff Safety at Iran Nuclear Plant
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said Russia sought and received assurances from Israel and the US that they’d ensure the safety of Russian staff working at Iran’s nuclear power plant at Bushehr.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: The reactor building at the Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr, Iran, in a handout image supplied by the Iran International Photo Agency.

item.title: Supreme Court Refuses to Expedite Challenge to Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The US Supreme Court refused to put a challenge to President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs on an ultra-fast track.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 20, 2025. President Donald Trump's administration urged the US Supreme Court to turn away a request for fast-track review of his sweeping tariffs, saying the justices should give lower courts more time to weigh in.

item.title: Putin Says He Isn’t Seeking Ukraine’s ‘Capitulation’ to End War
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said he isn’t seeking Ukraine’s “capitulation” as a way to end the war, even as he reiterated his claim that the two countries are one people.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Local residents look at damaged residential buildings following aa Russian drone attack in Odesa, on June 20.

item.title: NYC's Zohran Mamdani Tries Selling Socialism to the Home of Wall Street
item.description: For the full experience visit: NYC's Zohran Mamdani Tries Selling Socialism to the Home of Wall Street
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Zorhran Mamdani during a campaign event in New York on May 4. Photographer: Andrew Lichtenstein/Corbis News/Getty Images

item.title: Spain’s Indra Downplays Franco-German Sparring Over Fighter Jet
item.description: Indra Sistemas SA’s chairman sought to assuage doubts over Europe’s next-generation fighter-jet program, after disagreements between partners Dassault Aviation SA and Airbus SE broke into the open this week.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga

media:content.media:description: A full size model of the FCAS Future Combat Air System fighter under development by Dassault Aviation, Airbus and Indra Sistemas in Paris in 2023.

item.title: UN Chief Calls for Diplomacy as Israel-Iran War Rages
item.description: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for a return to negotiations to resolve the conflict between Israel and Iran, warning that the world is “on course to potential chaos” if it expands.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle, Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Israeli first responders enter a building that was hit by an Iranian strike in Haifa on June 20.

item.title: The US Has More Copper Than China But No Way to Refine All of It
item.description: The industry will need to overcome high energy and labor costs, environmental regulations and a glut of cheap Chinese competition to make US copper smelting great again.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, James Attwood, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Vessels and residual ore at the idled Asarco smelter in Hayden, Arizona.

item.title: Chip Stocks Slide on Report of New Possible Limits on China
item.description: Shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and other chipmakers slid on Friday after the Wall Street Journal reported that the Trump administration is considering further restrictions on China.
item.dc:creator: Dana Wollman, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: A robotic arm moves 300 mm silicon semiconductor wafers inside a sorting machine in a cleanroom at the Globalfoundries Inc. semiconductor fabrication plant in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday, Nov. 30, 2022. As the US has implemented unexpectedly strict rules on the transfer of semiconductor technology to China, the EU has paved the way for chipmakers to receive unprecedented state funds to build production sites as part of its EU Chips Act. Photographer: Liesa Johannssen/Bloomberg

item.title: UK House of Commons Approves Legalization of Assisted Dying
item.description: The UK’s House of Commons voted to legalize assisted dying on Friday, in a move that is likely to usher in a significant cultural shift over how to handle the treatment of those with terminal illnesses.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: The Houses of Parliament in London.

item.title: Switzerland Follows European Union in Lifting Sanctions on Syria
item.description: Switzerland is lifting economic sanctions on Syria, following an European Union decision to the same end.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the Syrian central bank in Damascus, Syria, on Monday, Dec. 23, 2024. The US lifted a $10 million bounty on Syria's de facto leader Ahmed Al-Sharaa after a US delegation met with him in Damascus.

item.title: Trump Hints He’ll Hold Off Iran Strike, Give Diplomacy Time
item.description: US President Donald Trump signaled he would give diplomacy a chance before deciding whether to strike Iran, dialing back on recent comments that suggested military action could be imminent.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Alisa Odenheimer, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: A firefighter walks past damage at Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, on June 19. Photographer: Leo Correa/AP Photo

item.title: EU Abandons Proposal to Lower Price Cap on Russian Oil to $45
item.description: The European Union shelved a plan for a stricter price cap on Russian oil exports over concerns that the US won’t back tougher sanctions due to rising crude prices.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Suzanne Lynch, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Oil pumping jacks in Russia.

item.title: UNAIDS Executive Director: ‘The HIV Response Is in Crisis’
item.description: Winnie Byanyima says her organization has lost almost 50% of its funding, a gap that is undermining global efforts to combat HIV/AIDS.
item.dc:creator: Mishal Husain
